description: Master Angular Forms: The easy Template-driven approach vs. the powerful Reactive Forms approach.

slides.title: Two Approaches
slides.content:
# Template vs Reactive ü•ä

1.  **Template-Driven:** Logic is in the HTML template. Simple, ideal for simple forms. Uses `FormsModule`.
2.  **Reactive Forms:** Logic is in the Component class. Explicit, testable, scalable. Uses `ReactiveFormsModule`.

slides.title: Template-Driven Setup
slides.content:
# Template Approach üìù

Must import `FormsModule`.

Use `[(ngModel)]` for two-way binding directly to a property.

```html
<input [(ngModel)]="user.name" name="name" required>
```
Angular automatically creates a FormControl for this input.

slides.title: Reactive Forms Setup
slides.content:
# Reactive Approach üèóÔ∏è

Must import `ReactiveFormsModule`.

Define the form model in the class:

```typescript
email = new FormControl('');
```

Bind it in the template:
```html
<input [formControl]="email">
```

slides.title: FormGroups
slides.content:
# FormGroup üì¶

Group multiple controls together.

```typescript
loginForm = new FormGroup({
  username: new FormControl(''),
  password: new FormControl('')
});
```

```html
<form [formGroup]="loginForm">
  <input formControlName="username">
</form>
```

slides.title: FormBuilder
Validators
slides.content:
# Validation üõ°Ô∏è

Built-in validators: `required`, `minLength`, `email`, `pattern`.

```typescript
this.email = new FormControl('', [
  Validators.required,
  Validators.email
]);
```
Check validity: `this.email.valid` or `this.email.errors`.

Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Forms üéì

Handling input.

- **Template-Driven:** Good for simple stuff (`[(ngModel)]`).
- **Reactive:** Good for complex logic (`FormControl`).
- **Validators:** Enforce rules.
- **FormGroup:** Group controls.
- **FormBuilder:** Helper utility.
